question.content:
**Graph $h(x)=4\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\right)+2$ in the interactive widget.**  
*Note that one moveable point always defines an extremum point in the graph and the other point always defines a neighbouring intersection with the midline.*

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
The basic function $\sin(x)$ intersects its midline at $(0,0)$ and has a maximum point at $\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2},1\right)$.

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9eab16ed8ecc31a4182d5255069119df911a194c.png)

Let's transform $\pink{\sin(x)}$ to $\blue{4\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\right)+2}$ step by step and see how the graph changes along the way.

The transformation from $\pink{\sin(x)}$ to $\green{\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x\right)}$ is a horizontal stretch by a factor of $\dfrac{4}{\pi}$, so the maximum point's horizontal distance from the origin is stretched from $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ to $\dfrac{\pi}{2}\cdot\dfrac{4}{\pi}=2$.

$\qquad$[[☃ image 1]]

The transformation from $\green{\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x\right)}$ to $\red{4\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x\right)}$ is a vertical stretch by a factor of $4$, so the maximum point's vertical distance from the origin is stretched from $1$ to $4$.

$\qquad$[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A dashed graph and a solid graph trigonometric wave on an x y coordinate plane. The x axis scales by pi and the y axis scales by one. On the dashed graph there is a point on the graph at the midline at (zero, zero) and a point at the maximum next to the mentioned point at (pi over two, one). On the solid graph, there is a point on the graph at the midline at (zero, zero) and a point at the maximum next to the mentioned point at (two, one).

A dashed graph and a solid graph trigonometric wave on an x y coordinate plane. The x axis scales by pi and the y axis scales by one. On the dashed graph there is a point on the graph at the midline at (zero, zero) and a point at the maximum next to the mentioned point at (two, one). On the solid graph, there is a point on the graph at the midline at (zero, zero) and a point at the maximum next to the mentioned point at (two, four).

hints.content: The transformation from $\red{4\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x\right)}$ to $\blue{4\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} x+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\right)+2}$, which is equivalent to $4\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4} (x+3)\right)+2$, is a translation to the left by $3$ units and a translation upwards by $2$ units.

As a result of these transformations, the intersection point with the midline is now at $\left(-3,2\right)$ and the maximum point is at $(-1,6)$.

The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A graph of a trigonometric wave on an x y coordinate plane. The x axis scales by one and the y axis scales by one. There is a point on the graph at the midline at (negative three, one) and a point on the maximum next to the mentioned point at (negative one, six).
